editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

NOW KNIGHT of BERK-SHIRE, Dictated by his own mouth, and took by Mr. Michael Old≈øworth ≈øometime his Lds Secretary, and faithfully engro≈ø≈øed; together with all his Lds. penitent con≈øiderations, (delivered in mo≈øt patheticall expre≈ø≈øions) upon every particular of his Goods, Catttels, Chattels, moveable and inmoveable, that are defigned in Legacy to ≈øundry particular per≈øons of mo≈øt eminent and remarkable quality.
The ≈øecond part to the ≈øame tune, will ≈øpeedily be exhibited to publique view, as ≈øoon as it can be po≈ø≈øibly Tran≈øcribed; By his Lds mo≈øt Devoted Honour.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: MY Lord de≈øiring to di≈øcover his Charitable and zealous intentions to the world, (more for pre≈øident then o≈øtentation) and at his la≈øt ga≈øpe re≈øolving to breath forth ≈øome pithy ≈øentences, (fit to be committed to po≈øterity in≈øtead of proverbs) that might ≈øpeake him to eternity, as full of wi≈ødom as worthine≈ø≈øe and honour, I here tender thee (by his Lord≈øhips appointment) the First part of his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament; pray make much of this, till the re≈øt is delivered to thee, under his owne Hand and Seale.

lg.l: In the mean time, weigh but each word with heed,
You'le thinke his Lord≈øhip meanes to dye indeed;
For by the≈øe gifts, I find he tru≈øts to merit
All th' heaven that e're's capacity'le inherit;
Nay in pure love, he is re≈øolv'd to ≈øhow
The Parliament the way they all must goe:
If he live longer, 'twill but vex the Devil
That ≈øuch a foole ≈øhould outwork him in evill.
Nay if he lives but to review this Will,
The kindne≈ø≈øe on't his very heart will kill:
I hope his Elegie and Epitaph
After the ≈øecond part on's Will, ≈øhall make you laugh.
And when we know his qualities, and riches,
Ile gage my braine-pan you'le be-pi≈ø≈øe your Breeches.

div.head: The fir≈øt part of the la≈øt WILL & TESTAMENT OF PHILIP Earle of Pembrook & Montgomery, &c.
div.p: I Philip Herbert of the Tilte-yard, in the Country of Saint James's Parke, lying very ≈øick and weak. Here Mr. Old≈øworth ≈øtop'd him, My Lord quoth he, you ≈øhould have begun in the Name of God. Dam me you Rogue, why do you Interupt me? is't not too late to begin with him now? I han't ≈øpoke with him ne're ≈øince I u≈øed to ≈øing P≈øalmes in the Kings Chappel, ≈øome eight years agoe, and do≈øt thinke he has not other things to think on be≈øides my bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, I ne're medled with his Will, and why ≈øhould he have any hand in mine; Mr. Speaker knows, I have more mind to make him my Executor (or the Devil take me el≈øe) I promi≈øed him ≈øo when he got me into the Hou≈øe of Commons; and be≈øides, Mr. Speaker has rea≈øon to love me better then he, becau≈øe he knows me better; the Parliament would count me a Cock≈øcomb to for≈øake them at la≈øt ca≈øt, and give my Meanes to one that I ≈øhall never ≈øee for ought I know: Mihill I thought th' had≈øt had more wit then to per≈øwade me to any thing but what I am bound to by Act of Parliament, and I am ≈øure there's ne're a ≈øuch a word in any of them by my con≈øent, or ever ≈øhall be; therefore pray hold your tongue and let me ≈øpeake my own purpo≈øe, and do you write it down, right or wrong; when you lye a dying (as I do) if you'le teach me to Write, Ile do your will to your mind.

But yet in perfect health and memory do make and (pox confound the≈øe hard words) pro≈øtitute this my la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament, and hereby doe invoke and make voide all other Gifts, (the Devil a one I remember) Grants, Conveyances (and mine were never cleanly ones, for when I jugled my ≈øelf out of one Hou≈øe intoth' tother, all the Towne tooke notice of my ≈øhuffling under board) Wils and Te≈øtaments what≈øoever.

sp.speaker: Old≈øw.
sp.p: Former, my Lord, you mu≈øt ≈øay, Former Wils.

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.p:
Why did I ever lye a dying afore you foole you? won't one Will
≈øerve turn; you woo'd have me hang'd for making a new Letanie of repealed wils and Te≈øtaments; woo'd ye?
Imprimis, I give and bequeath my be≈øt pack of dogs ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Old≈øw.
sp.p: My Lord, do you remember what to do with your ≈øoul and body fir≈øt?

sp.speaker: Pemb.
sp.p: Vengeance dam ye for a confounded Cur, I could find in my heart to da≈øh a pi≈øpot in your ugly face; ≈øo ye'd ≈øerve me an I were at praiers, but I'le ≈øee ye hang'd before I'le try ye: Can I tel who ≈øhal have my body or ≈øoul either? Have I been Ma≈øter of my ≈øelf e're ≈øince I was born? Did not I pawn my ≈øoul and ≈øalvation too, long ≈øince to the King (though I ne're hop'd to redeem it) when I was made his turn-key? And did not the Parliament get it out on's cluches into their paws, e're they would make me their Porter to carry Packets of Propo≈øitions to, and again? They may do what they wil with't; for my part, I ne're made much u≈øe on't, becau≈øe I ne're knew wel what it was: For my body, I mean to keep it my ≈øelf as long as I can, I'le give every thing el≈øe away to the Devil him≈øelf, rather then part with my Carca≈ø≈øe; I'me ≈øure my Confectionarie's Bill t'other day came to 100l. and I'de fain fatten my kidneys with tho≈øe ≈øweet meats before I die, for fear they grow mouldy: I have no mind to feed upon gravel yet; an' my con≈øcience the pigmies do, and that makes them ≈øuch dwarfs: I'de rather go to hel, or purgatory, where there's room enough for a coach and ≈øix hor≈øes to turn, then be mew'd up under ground, where a man cannot ≈øwing and Cat; but prethee hold thy tongue, and let's mind our bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, for I ≈øhan't die in quiet, til I ≈øee my dogs provided for.

My be≈øt pack of dogs to Oliver Cromwel, for he keeps bloud-hounds ≈øo wel fle≈øh'd and fierce, they're able to tear out the Devils throat: I wonder what he feeds with them, now ox livers are ≈øo dear.

Item, I bequeath two couple of my be≈øt ≈øpaniels to my Lord of Denbigh, for hee'l ≈øtand gazing like a moap'd Buzzard, and gape wide enough for a Hawk to ≈øhit in's mouth, whil'≈øt a Partridge is upon replinie: ≈øtoo bird, ≈øtoo bird, O 'tis gallant game; I wonder whether there be any Haws in Hel; an' I thought there were not, I'de ≈øend half a ≈øcore thither a mewing by Tom my Faulkner again≈øt I come, I ≈øhall ne're endure to be idle there.

sp.speaker: Old≈øw.
sp.p: You left at There, my Lord.

div.p:
There rogue, what ≈øhall I do without thee there? Thou mu≈øt needs make me a ≈øpeech to carry I' my pocket, I'le con't by the way; they ≈øay the Devil's a good Scholar, he hope Harry Martin to an≈øwer the Scots papers, and make the Declaration of Non-Addre≈ø≈øes to His Maje≈øtie: They ≈øay his Secretarie pen'd that pithy Oration that Brad≈øhaw made before the ≈øentence: Hang't, I ≈øhall ne're come off, without thou prompt≈øt me, hee'l da≈øh me out a countenance, becau≈øe he ≈øpeaks Latin; ju≈øt as he does the poor rogues that cannot reade their neck-ver≈øe before my Lord Judge: ‚Äî Confound me, if he angers me too much, I'le ≈øwear his hou≈øe about's ears, if I can but get my Lord Generals pa≈ø≈øe to run back again; if he denies that, I'de be≈øt take a file of musketeers we' me, and bring him before the Councel of War, to an≈øwer the contempt: But come, di≈øpatch Mihil, prethee write on, thou art ≈øo tedious, I doubt I ≈øhall not get this Will ingro≈ø≈øed time enough
to take a Copy out we' me; for I mean to ≈øue my Executers there for non performance, if I can entertain Mr Chute, or Mr Whitlock, for my Councel, and Sergeant Wild ≈øhall have the hearing of the cau≈øe; hee'l be ≈øure to hang 'um o' my con≈øcience, 'un he take 'um ta dy there, becau≈øe 'tis a bigger Court of Ju≈øtice then ours in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall.

Item, I give Badger, my be≈øt ≈øtone hor≈øe (plague take him, for he threw me two damnable
‚Ä¢ quei ‚Ä¢ hes one Saint George's day, I ne're daw'd it ≈øince) to Colonel Henry Martin; he has hors'd me above a 100 coach mares in's time; he has ≈øome pith in's back ≈øtil, you may ≈øee by his frothing and blundring, when ≈øees a hand≈øom Bea≈øt; he leaps nimbly ≈øtil, but he comes off ba≈øely, becau≈øe of an old wrinch he got with ≈øtraining too hard in jumping upon a great Flanders jade, too ful buttock'd for him, and upon a bank≈øide too.

Item, I give and bequeath my Tenor, my Ba≈øe, and my Treble, and all my Horns, to my wel beloved Son and Heir, Philip Lord Herbert; his Wife can teach him to wind them, or the pox take her, for the French man has been her Tutor long enough; I lov'd the mu≈øick wel, but I could never endure to were 'um, they made me look ≈øo like a ≈øow-gelder.

Item, I give and bequeath my be≈øt lacing boots to Mr Speaker (rot on 'um, I never wore 'um, but men thought I had got the gout for the ≈øpavin; they'l ne're ≈øu≈øpect him, becau≈øe he limps o'th' toe ≈øide like a Craw-fi≈øh.

Item, I give and bequeath my rich Sedan ‚Äî woons, I'de fain be rid on't, becau≈øe they carried the King to triall in't; I ne're ≈øate in't ≈øince, but I was ready to be≈øhit my ≈øelf for fear; an' I could but think of any body the Devil ows a ≈øpight to, to betray him for a Traitor, he ≈øhould ha't; 't may be my Lord Say wil thank me for't: Set him down in't, for he loves to take's ca≈øe wel.

Item, I give and bequeath my new tru≈ø≈øe of points ‚Äî hart, the rogues took me for a morri≈ø-dancer in a morning before I was tru≈øs'd, when they came to cro≈ø≈øe capers, and dance attendance before my honourable Wor≈øhip: I'de be≈øt give them to Mr Selden to keep's codpice clo≈øe; hee'l wear 'um for antick fa≈øhion ≈øake; he ≈øhall have Tib, my gray mare too; the Counte≈ø≈øe of Kent knows hee'l ≈øtride an old gal'd jade ≈øo gently, that ≈øhee'l ne're wince at it; I cou'd find I my heart to give him her crupper too, for ≈øhe ca≈øts forward damnably: Set him down for a mounter.

Item, I give and bequeath my great gaudy Coach (wood't had been burned for me, when I ≈øet foot in't; I'le take my death on't, I thought the Devil had been in't, and his dam too, when I and my Lady Crompton rid in't la≈øt, it rumbled our rotten bones together like dice in a jugling box; dam 'om 'twas as bad as are of the≈øe confounded Strapadoes; pox on't, an' I had ne're hunted baudy hou≈øes, I might have rid hone≈øtly up Holborn hil without any danger, but it made me tremble like a rogue as I was, to think on't, how the Traitors that ride that way are mangled, when they came at Tyburn; and I was never ≈øo fraid but my quarters woo'd have been ≈øhoke off before I came to Hide Park corner; I'de be≈øt giv't) to my Lord Grey of Groby, for hee's fain to make u≈øe of a Hackney ≈øtil to ≈øave charges, when's
‚Ä¢ udy rides a ranting, let him take't with a pox to him, for I have enough
on't, more then e're I ≈øhall well claw of.

Item, I give and bequeath my great gilt Bible; Fool-≈øcratch 'um, the puppies took me for a Puritan; and ‚Äî judge me, may I nere ≈øtir if I had not rather hear Bul≈øtrode Whitlocks Declarations read 100 times, then one of Paul Knels Sermon of execration again≈øt Rebels, becau≈øe I fumbled over the leaves, as if I meant to find the Text, though I nere knew a figure from a frying pan; I could ≈øtare Caryl i'th' face upon a Fa≈øt day (like an Owl as I was) til the Gander was ready to be cackle him≈øelf for fear I ≈øhould put him out on's parrating: Tis a terrible villain ≈øometimes, for hee'l make a Church roar of damnation as bad as a Popes Bull, hee'l ≈øo be labour a poor innocent cu≈øhion, as if he meant to beat the brains out about's ears, as he rears up again≈øt the pillar ‚Äî yet ≈øometime hee'l give's a great deal of comfort, when he was terrified us a matter of two hours together with a thundring ≈øtory of Cromwel's plaguy deliverances, and murdered our memories with his morter-peece of de≈øtruction to Monarchy; then he begins to bleat peaceably towards dinner time; O tis a cunning colt, he knows how to kick us out of good manners, and make's whihy again to hear him claw into conceit with our own mi≈øchiefs; I had be≈øt give him this Bible, hee'l preach nothing but Acts of Parliament, and Judge Advocate Orders out on't, to ≈øtrengthen the hearts of the couragious Councel of War, that they may confidently condemn the rogues without the lea≈øt ≈øcruple of ≈øcurvy con≈øcience: Set him down for a Book banger.

Item, I give and bequeath my be≈øt Cloake and George; vengeance of all ill luck: an I wear't any longer, the bloud thir≈øty will go nigh to take me for a Tyrant (as fierce a one as ere ≈øtood in Smithfield pens) and fix me for a blazing ≈øtar in the fore-head of the Firmament for the world to wonder at, how the Devil I came there again≈øt my will; for they knew I nere lov'd climbing (a rope fetch me if ere I did, ≈øo I did not) if I had, I had nere been cho≈øen Knight of Bark ≈øhire by ≈øome twenty of my vainglorious Tenants and Servants, that thir≈øted to do their Lord an honour; on my con≈øcience tis dangerous to be Knighted too by the≈øe ≈øla≈øhing blades, for fear a mans head ≈øhould fall into's codpice; I could nere endure to ≈øee a ≈øword drawn, ≈øince I was beaten with my own hilts by a Butchers boy cro≈ø≈øing the kennel, becau≈øe I, like a great Calf, mu≈øt needs call him tallowbeard, though his face was as bald as my own pate: and though they would not hang thee in it for a counterfeit, thou ≈øhould≈øt have my Ribbon and George, 'twas my Porters armes, or I had nere been known to ≈øit at the receipt of cu≈øtom in the Parliament Hou≈øe, and carry tickets to and fro between party and party; a lou≈øe in the pot, Mihil, is better then no fle≈øh; a Porters place in the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe will be good preferment for an old Parliament man, in the raign of a new Repre≈øentative: I alwaies liked the conceit o'th' Emblem, more then th'honour on't (for that never fitted my humour) it looks fiercely, but when ye come to touch it, tis as tame as a dotterill: And be≈øides ye know, when I am on hor≈øback, I oo≈øe as little motion as may be; on my con≈øcience they'l go nigh to take't for my Lord Generals picture, if thou laye≈øt it on a bow knot in thy bo≈øom; for hee's a man of a meek temper, or el≈øe he would never let Cromwel rule the ro≈øt, while he
turns the ≈øpit, and you know your Cooks are fiery fellows. I'le give my Cloake to Sir Henry Vane, for 'twill cover more knavery then foolery; and in this time of turning things ar≈øe upwards, the badges of honour may well become di≈øtingui≈øhing Characters of infamy, the ≈øtar will illu≈øtrate all his contrivances; we had be≈øt leave off for this bout, for too much of one thing is good for nothing; I'me out of breath now, but I'le fall too't again too morrow, and give um all enough afore I have done with them, that they may pray for me, while I ≈øwear um all out of hell.
